awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal:  MRA:  Linking land-to-water transport and stream carbon cycling to inform macrosystem carbon balance
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon is the energy currency of ecosystems. Carbon emissions from streams and rivers are important sources of carbon to the atmosphere. Scientists rarely measure the movement of carbon from air to plants, into soils and groundwater, through streams and rivers, and back to the atmosphere. This research will develop new methods and data to measure terrestrial carbon cycling through freshwaters. This project will also train diverse students and professionals to conduct research linking terrestrial and freshwater carbon flows. Educators will complete summer research projects using environmental sensors and public datasets to enhance K-12 student understanding of research. Collaborations with industry partners will create common standards for freshwater sensor measurements. The project will also develop open-source software to improve water quality and carbon cycling research with data collected by sensors. 

The movement of terrestrial carbon across land-water boundaries controls the carbon balance of watersheds and the metabolism of freshwater ecosystems. Streams are the primary interface between terrestrial and freshwater ecosystems. They are ideal testbeds to advance understanding of land-water carbon transfers and meta-ecosystem ecology (i.e., the study of multiple ecosystems linked by energy and material transfers). This research seeks to answer the questions: (1) What is the magnitude and variability of land-to-water carbon transfers and stream carbon emissions in watershed carbon balances? (2) What controls carbon form, cycling, and fate in meta-ecosystems? (3) How does meta-ecosystem carbon cycling in different parts of the United States vary within and among years? The factors regulating carbon metabolism and emissions are predicted to operate at different spatial and temporal scales. Environmental sensors and water chemistry sampling will capture the temporal variability in carbon cycling and losses in soils and streams at paired terrestrial-aquatic National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) research sites across the United States. Project outcomes will advance a predictive understanding of the daily, seasonal, and annual processes controlling watershed carbon cycling through measurements and models that cross land-water boundaries and approaches that integrate biology, geology, and chemistry across space and time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems are connected via the transfer of carbon in various forms. Due to the complexity of these ecosystems, terrestrial and aquatic ecologists often study the carbon cycle separately. As a result, these studies do not represent the loss of carbon from land to water. This can lead to inaccurate estimation of carbon storage (or emission) in terrestrial ecosystems. Similarly, if this exchange is unaccounted for, carbon emission from streams and rivers are solely attributed to carbon originating within aquatic systems, while in reality, a significant portion originates from terrestrial systems due to exchange. We also do not understand how this exchange flux varies over different ecosystems and regions across the continental United States with distinct variations in climate. Our lack of understanding also limits our ability to predict how a variable and changing climate may affect this export of terrestrial carbon to freshwater systems and its role in climate feedbacks. The National Ecological Observation Network (NEON) provides for the first time the coupled data sets needed to understand the terrestrial-aquatic carbon linkage across the various regions of the United States, from Puerto Rico to Alaska, and locations in between.

This project integrated NEON data sets in a simple soil model that calculates the transfer of dissolved inorganic carbon from different terrestrial ecosystems to aquatic ecosystems across United States. The modeling analysis showed that dissolved inorganic carbon export from watersheds are relatively small compared to CO2 emission from soil to the atmosphere. Though smaller compared to these emissions, it can be a larger fraction of what the watershed is observed to store based on net gas exchange measured above the canopy. Depending on the ecosystem and accounting for uncertainty, the model predicts <1% to 18% of NEE being exported to streams from terrestrial systems. This is important because when not considered, our estimates of watershed carbon storage will be overestimated (or emission underestimated if the ecosystem is a source of carbon). Further, watershed scale properties, such as amount of precipitation and stored soil organic carbon, act similarly on both emission of CO2 from the soil and export as dissolved carbon, though the actual magnitude of the effect varies depending on site. Overall, our results provide a novel understanding of the carbon cycle linkages between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems and have the potential to improve next generation ecosystem models.

Broader Impacts:

This work will benefit scientists who are trying to understand the feedbacks between ecosystems and the atmosphere and how they will respond to changing temperatures. The model codes will be shared through an online database, GitHub, for future use by scientific communities. The results were shared with scientists across disciplines and research labs through peer-reviewed publication that are in preparation, public presentations and collaboration. This project heavily relied on NEON data infrastructure, which is planned to operate for 30 years, meaning the results can be updated over the entire lifespan of the NEON. This work has directly supported doctoral research activities of 3 graduate student, initiated a multi-institutional collaboration of a scale not done before and generated unique ecosystem scale datasets and findings, which are valuable for scientific communities.
